item.title: About
item.author: samuel.franklin@port.ac.uk (Sam Franklin)
item.description:
CV
#

Academic CV, PhD researcher at ICG Portsmouth. Details on education, publications & presentations, and teaching experience.

Title

Recent Conferences, Schools, Workshops, Talks and Posters
#

  • Nordic Winter School on Black Holes and Gravitational Waves; University of Copenhagen; Skeikampen, Norway - 2026
  • GRADnet Expo, International Student House; SEPnet; London, UK -2025
  • BUSSTEP; University of Nottingham, UK - 2025
  • Black Hole Mini Workshop; University of Portsmouth, UK - 2025
  • XV NExT PhD Workshop; SEPnet; Abingdon, UK - 2025 - Awarded Best Talk
  • Faculty of Technology R&I Conference; University of Portsmouth, UK - 2025 - Awarded Best Poster
  • South Coast Cosmology Meeting; University of Portsmouth, UK - 2025
  • London cosmology discussion meeting; Queen Mary University; Royal Astronomical Society, London, UK - 2025
  • Introduction to Astronomy; STFC; Keele University, UK - 2024

item.title: When will the Last Total Solar Eclipse Take Place?
item.author: samuel.franklin@port.ac.uk (Sam Franklin)
item.description: When will the last total solar eclipse occur? This physics coursework models tidal acceleration to predict the final event in roughly 530 million years.

item.title: MPhys Paper
item.author: samuel.franklin@port.ac.uk (Sam Franklin)
item.description: Can pulsar winds explain GRB afterglow plateaus? My thesis uses relativistic hydrodynamics to model energy injection and recreate data from Swift observations.

item.title: Black Hole Isospectrality Poster
item.author: samuel.franklin@port.ac.uk (Sam Franklin)
item.description: A scientific poster titled ‘Black Hole Isospectrality’ by Samuel Franklin et al. from ICG Portsmouth.

item.title: New Types of Gravitational Waves
item.author: samuel.franklin@port.ac.uk (Sam Franklin)
item.description: Have we missed a hidden signal in black hole mergers? Discover ‘direct waves’—a newly observed gravitational signature found in the GW250114 event.

item.title: Research
item.author: samuel.franklin@port.ac.uk (Sam Franklin)
item.description:
Quantum Black Holes and their Gravitational Waves
#

My main research centres on the is the gravtiational waves emitted by a black hole spacetime after it has been “perturbed”, meaning it has been changed by some relatively small amount. Several events can cause such a perturbation for example close encounters with other compact objects or stellar tidal distruption events. Currently, the most important way this happens is in the aftermath of a compact object merger which has the added benefit of generating an inspiral and merger signal that can be detected by the LIGO, VERGO and KAGRA gravitaitonal wave detectors.

item.title: Cryptic Secrets: The Pit
item.author: samuel.franklin@port.ac.uk (Sam Franklin)
item.description: Escape the Goblin King in ‘The Pit,’ a system-agnostic TTRPG oneshot. This low-level mini-dungeon features arena combat, puzzles, and classic tropes.
